results.title: Getting around
results.creator_credit: Robin James, ABC-TV (Australia), Asian Studies Council and Griffith University
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Dragons tongue. - Series 2.”.
In this Chinese language program, Professor Colin Mackerras explores the Public Transport system in Beijing. This is heavily used as cars are a rarity. Buses are in great demand and overcrowded. Trains are more modern and luxurious by comparison, while bicycles are by far the most common form of transport. This episode illustrates the vocabulary and protocols required to use the Public Transport system effectively. Presents a sequence looking at the history of the Chinese Language and the confusion which can arise when words sound the same but have different meaning.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robin James, ABC-TV (Australia), Asian Studies Council and Griffith University

results.title: School days
results.creator_credit: Robin James, ABC-TV (Australia), Asian Studies Council and Griffith University
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Dragons tongue. - Series 2.”.
Professor Colin Mackerras visits a primary school in Beijing. Chinese schools follow a traditional curricula where the emphasis is on reading, writing and mathematics. Facilities are often simple and the teaching using the traditional “chalk and talk” method. Schools are responsible for teaching the importance of birth control and hygiene to students as well as giving them a moral and political education. Outside the classroom students play Chinese games such as “elastics”. The program also looks at the importance of radical characters in Chinese writing.

results.title: A Sporting life
results.creator_credit: Robin James, ABC-TV (Australia), Asian Studies Council and Griffith University
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Dragons tongue. - Series 2.”.
In this Chinese language program, Professor Colin Mackerras looks at popular sports and physical activities in China. Basketball is rising in popularity and China used its excellence in Ping Pong for diplomacy when it was re-opening its doors to the world. Physical education in schools is seen as very important, while Mao Tse-tung encouraged participation in the martial arts as a way of developing a physically, morally and spiritually sound country. The program also examines the different writing styles and the emphasis on balance and movement in forming characters.

results.title: Entertainment
results.creator_credit: Robin James, ABC-TV (Australia), Asian Studies Council and Griffith University
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Dragons tongue. - Series 2.”.
In this Chinese language program, Professor Colin Mackerras looks at recreational activities in China. Cinema going is particularly popular and European and American films are being shown more frequently. The Peking Opera is a much loved and traditional art form, steeped in cultural heritage. Although it is not as popular amongst young Chinese, tourists love the rich pageantry. The Chinese also love outdoor events in parks and on waterways. The composition of Chinese characters in Chinese writing is also examined.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robin James, ABC-TV (Australia), Asian Studies Council and Griffith University

results.title: Health
results.creator_credit: Robin James, ABC-TV (Australia), Asian Studies Council and Griffith University
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Dragons tongue. - Series 2.”.
In this Chinese language program, Professor Colin Mackerras explores the many ways in which the Chinese people look after their health. Hospitals may be run by Government Departments for workers. Apart from conventional medicine, traditional therapies such as Acupuncture and Moxibustion are widely accepted. Herbal remedies are also important to Chinese medicine and many pharmacies carry both manufactured drugs and herbal treatments. This program also looks at the composition of a character when practising calligraphy.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robin James, ABC-TV (Australia), Asian Studies Council and Griffith University

results.title: Families
results.creator_credit: Robin James, ABC-TV (Australia), Asian Studies Council and Griffith University
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Dragons tongue. - Series 2.”.
In this Chinese language program, Professor Colin Mackerras looks at the importance of family in Chinese culture, especially since the law restricted family size to one child in order to contain the population. Chinese Law since the 1950’s forbade polygamy and arranged marriages, and now young people can choose their own partners. The status of women and girls is discussed and the problems encountered raising single children. The program also looks at oracle bones and how these lead to the creation of written language.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robin James, ABC-TV (Australia), Asian Studies Council and Griffith University

results.title: Playing Fair
results.creator_credit: Penny Ritco, Wolf Koenig and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A series of four dramas for 7-12 year olds intended to promote discussion on the issues of racism, respect and equality for children. Each episode revolves around a conflict where a child is taunted and discriminated against because they are a member of a minority group. The situations are credible and expose the impact of such behaviour on children.

results.title: Walker
results.creator_credit: Alanis Obomsawin, Penny Ritco, Wolf Koenig and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Playing Fair”.
Walker is a young American Indian boy who has tragically lost his parents and is now fostered by another American Indian family. His only playmate and real companion is his dog. Jamie, a lonely young white boy has been made afraid, not only of dogs, but of people who are not white. Walker ignores the racist taunts and jeerings of the older boys who have influenced Jamie, and reaches out to him. Together they find friendship and understanding as Jamie learns to conquer his fears.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Alanis Obomsawin, Penny Ritco, Wolf Koenig and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Hey, Kelly!
results.creator_credit: Sook-Yin Lee, Penny Ritco, Wolf Koenig and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Playing Fair”.
During a friendly game of tag, Robert calls Kelly a racist name and a fight ensues. Both Kelly and Robert are given detention, and the Principal gives them a task where they must co-operate in order to achieve the desired end. It is through this co-operation and working together, that Robert realises that he has a great deal in common with Kelly, and that her “difference” is only “skin-deep”.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Sook-Yin Lee, Penny Ritco, Wolf Koenig and National Film Board of Canada

Episode of Series “Playing Fair”.
During a friendly game of tag, Robert calls Kelly a racist name and a fight ensues. Both Kelly and Robert are given detention, and the Principal gives them a task where they must co-operate in order to achieve the desired end. It is through this co-operation and working together, that Robert realises that he has a great deal in common with Kelly, and that her “difference” is only “skin-deep”.

results.title: Mela's lunch
results.creator_credit: Sugith Varughese, Penny Ritco, Wolf Koenig and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Playing Fair”.
Mela has just immigrated from India to Canada and is trying to settle into a new environment. Finding new friends and getting used to new surroundings becomes difficult because Peter and his classmates are determined to make her feel unwelcome and out of place. They jeer at her because her lunch is different and initially Allison goes along with the group, but realises this is unfair. Her decision to stick by Mela and to get to know her better demonstrate that differences in skin colour and country of origin should not be an obstacle to friendship and self-esteem.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Sugith Varughese, Penny Ritco, Wolf Koenig and National Film Board of Canada
